title: funfair mum claire danter combats ptsd book writing
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityClaire Danter and India Danter have teamed up to produce Nelson#s Funfair Holtspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtliday lt spangtlt spangt" Funfair mum Claire Danter combats PTSD with children#s book writingClaire Danter and India Danter have used their experiences in their book#s pltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtroductionlt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA MUM from a travelling funfair family has traded on her experience of post-traumatic stress disorderto produce a childrenrsquos book available from Waterstones and Amazon.Claire Danter, writing under the name of Claire Carey, wrote Nelsons Funfair Holiday more than a year ago, having turned to writing as a form of therapy after she was attacked.Mrs Danter, , and husband James and sons James Jnr and Jonathan were part of the reopening of Barry Island Pleasure Park in  and stayed for three seasons.Her niece India Danter, who has illustrated the book, was born in Newport, moved to Caldicot and grew up on the funfair travelling around South Wales with her parents at Caldicot, Abergavenny, Cwmbran, Newport, and Cardf.Pleasure Park owners hit with order to stop calling ferris wheel the "Barry Eye"Barry Islands Ferris Wheel under threat due to planning disputePleasure Park rides due on site in three weeksMrs Danter said: ldquoMy journey to becoming a writer is the classic story of turning negative into positive.ldquoI started writing just after I suffered an attack - it was an unexpected vicious attack by another woman.ldquoAfter the attack I started to suffer from PTSD.ldquoI visited my doctor many times, how could I have PTSD ldquoI hadnt been to the front line.ldquoMy doctor told me it only takes one traumatic event or one moment when you believe your le could be lost.ldquoThe mental burden of PTSD is dreadful.ldquoI wouldnt wish that on anybody.ldquoIt has taken me over two years of my le to get to somewhere near normal and even now Im not the same person I was.ldquoThe writing was the escape I needed.ldquoWriting has aided my recovery so far and I would recommend this to anyone suffering from PTSD.ldquoAlthough Im left with the scars of PTSD, itrsquos is behind me now.ldquoWriting has now become a hobby for me and the sense of achievement - holding a published book in your hands that you have written is the best feeling.ldquoItrsquos great.Mrs Danter drew inspiration from a childrenrsquos book which she personally found horrying.ldquoI saw a childrens book called Dex and the Funfair by Paul Shipton.ldquoIn my opinion the story is shocking.ldquoEvenI wasnt part of the funfair industry myself, I wouldnt want my children to read such a book.ldquoThe worst part about this, is the book is fact that it is in some school libraries.The book details Dex smashing up a tin can alley stall and the stallholder giving Dex a prize to make him leave.ldquoThis is shocking on all levels, she said. ldquoAllowing children to read books like this at the age of five or six cannot be a good thing.ldquoMy second inspiration came when my nephew came on holiday with while we were on our travels, which in turn reminded me just how much fun it was growing up on the fairground.ldquoI decided to write Nelsons Funfair Holiday - a story about a little boy who goes to stay with his auntie who owns a funfair.ldquoThis story will give children a glimpse of what it is like visiting and growing up on the fairground.ldquoChildren in my opinion must have all the experiences le has to offer to broaden their minds ready for the wider world.ldquoTravelling fairgrounds are part of our heritage in the UK and across Europe.ldquoItrsquos our history, its who we are and we are all play a part in that, whether you grow up on the fairground or not.The Danters originally hail from Brynmawr.Goff Danter, an artist, was able to offer India tips and advice on illustrating the book which is her first having previously been commissioned to do pencil drawings under the trade name Romayne Art.Mrs Danter also has another book under her belt.Entitled Me and My Social Media, itrsquos a short, gripping story about the dark side of social media and how a perfectly normal family can be turned upside down.ldquoI am very proud of this book, she added. ldquoEverybody who reads it tells me they cannot put it until they have finished it.Nelsons Funfair Holiday costs pound. and is available from Amazon and Waterstones. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: change face coverings policy wales schools colleges
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Welsh Government has updated its operational guidance on the use of face coverings in secondary schools and colleges.The guidance now states that face coverings should be worn:bull in all areas outside the classroom by staff and learners in secondary schools and collegesbull on dedicated school and college transport for learners in year  and upbull by visitors to all schools and colleges, including parents and carers dropping off and picking up childrenThe move follows the publication of SAGE evidence and a recent TAG report.MORE STORIESFace covering funds for secondary school and FE collegesFace coverings to become mandatory in Wales on public transportBarry pharmacist and spaniel spread wearing face covering correctly messageEducation minister, Kirsty Williams said: ldquoIt is vital that young people, parents, adults and the workforce feel confident that all measures are being taken to ensure the educational environments are as safe as possible.ldquoWe have been clear that we will keep every policy under review and will continue to follow scientic advice.ldquoThe new guidance is simple to follow, easier to administer and ensures that there is a consistent policy across Wales."We have already announced funding of pound.m to support the purchasing of face coverings in secondary schools and colleges.ldquoSocial distancing and washing hands remain the most important measures that everyone in Wales must continue to take."Wearing face coverings can complement these measures, ensuring we are doing everything we can to keep ourselves and others safe.ldquoEveryone in Wales has an important part to play in helping to prevent the spread of coronavirus and keep each other safe."This includes staying out of each otherrsquos homes, except in very limited circumstances, limiting how many dferent people we meet, maintaining social distancing and washing hands regularly.ldquoWe will be working with schools and colleges to help reinforce the messages to pupils, parents and staff on the importance of taking responsibility to help save lives and protect our NHS.The Welsh Governmentrsquos policy for face coverings in classrooms remains the same.In classrooms where contact groups exist and other control measures are in place, the marginal benefit that may be gained by the use of face coverings has to be balanced with the likely negative impact on the learning experience, including hearing and social communication.Prevention should be the primary aim of all control measures and experience to date suggests that prevention measures have been well understood and widely implemented across our schools and colleges. article_url   content_id   site_id dear.ldquoToday, I met the First Ministers of Scotland and Northern Ireland and Michael Gove, from the UK Government, and Irsquom pleased we were able to agree a common four-nation plan for the festive period.MORE STORIESWhat you need to know about Cardf Bus Christmas travelHow to help brighten up Christmas on Barry Island boatsWho now qualies for  per cent off Morrisons groceries The text, of a joint statement issued by the four UK governments, said: As  draws to a close, we recognise it has been an incredibly dficult year for us all.We have all had to make signicant sacrices in our everyday lives, and many religious and community groups have already had to change or forgo their customary celebrations to slow the spread of coronavirus and save lives.This cannot be a lsquonormalrsquo Christmas.But as we approach the festive period, we have been working closely together to find a way for family and friends to see each other, evenit is for a short time, and recognising that it must be both limited and cautious.Even where it is within the rules, meeting with friends and family over Christmas will be a personal judgement for iniduals to take, mindful of the risks to themselves and others, particularly those who are vulnerable.We need everyone to think carefully about what they do during this period, balancing some increased social contact with the need to keep the risk of increased transmission of the virus as low as possible.This is particularly important when considering those who are vulnerable, and before deciding to come together over the festive period we urge the consideration of alternative approaches such as the use of technology or meeting outside.In this context, the four administrations have reached agreement on a single set of UK-wide measures to help people come together with their loved ones in a way that is as safe as possible.Today we have agreed that:bull Travel restrictions across the four administrations and between tiers will be lted to provide a window for households to come together between December  and December.bull Up to three households can form an exclusive lsquobubblersquo to meet at home during this period. When a bubble is formed it is fixed, and must not be changed or extended further at any point.bull Each Christmas bubble can meet at home, at a place of worship or an outdoor public place, but existing, more restrictive rules on hospitality and meeting in other venues will be maintained throughout this period.It is important that everyone respects and abides by the rules of each nation wherever they choose to spend the festive period.Where there are any iations in our approach, these will be communicated by each administration accordingly.Further guidance will be provided in due course.The winter holiday period is a time often spent with family and friends, with schools and offices closing and people travelling over the bank holidays.Many have already begun making their plans, and we are today providing clarity to help people make the right choices for them, and enjoy time with those closest to them while staying within the rules to protect us all. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: findings review penarth streets linked slavery
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityClive Place, Clive Crescent, and the Clive Arms Hotel were all deemed in the green category, meaning ldquopersons of interest are not commemorated.The review advises that while the names are associated with colonist Lord Robert Clive, they do not commemorate him.Plassey Street, which had been marked as another potential link to slavery, was not included in the audit review.The report was commissioned by First Minister Mark Drakeford in July in response to the death of George Floyd and the Black Lives Matter protests.Published yesterday, the audit was led by Gaynor Legall, and shows the slave trade was embedded in the Welsh economy and society and reflected in many statues, street and building names today.It identied  monuments, buildings or street names, located in all parts of Wales, which commemorate people who were directly involved with the slavery and the slave trade or opposed its abolition.The Vale council is carrying out its own review, with a deadline for suggested commemorations to be reviewed set for January .Hilary Brown, co-chairman of Stand Up To Racism Vale, which has been invited on the councilrsquos task board to discuss links to slavery in the region, said: ldquoItrsquos important to undertake an audit evenit is decided that no street or building names in the Vale should be removed. and Hilary Brown at a protest calling for a review" alt"Penarth Times: Vale protesters Bianca Aliand Hilary Brown at a protest calling for a review" class"editor-image"Vale protesters Bianca Aliand Hilary Brown at a protest calling for a reviewldquoWe feel it is important to teach everyone about the history of these names, and to tell the stories of how these names came to be. A separate discussion to that is what needs to be doneit is decided these names should not have been given in the first place.ldquoI would like to see the findings of the Welsh Government audit properly shared with the Vale council, prior to consultation with us.ldquoWe havenrsquot heard from the Vale council at all on this. We are waiting with baited breath for that to happen.Resident Nick Schroeter welcomed the findings of the review, saying: ldquoWe are talking about things that happened hundreds of years ago, and slavery is such a erse topic and has happened throughout history.ldquoIrsquom not saying itrsquos right, but I do believe we need to learn from it and move on.Stand Up To Racism protesters outside the Civic Offices, Barry, over the Valersquos connections to slaveryldquoEventhese road names were changed, people will still call them the same names. I feel especially during a pandemic these reviews are a waste of resources.Dinas resident Richard Winder added: ldquoThis generation needs to be aware of this stain on our history and to know of the terrible conditions on the slave ships and in the plantations, and also of the inhumanity of the gang masters and of the unimaginable obscenities of the punishments handed out.ldquoIf this means changing street names, moving statues, or educating as to how the money to build many of our great historic houses came from, then so be it.ldquoWe cannot change the past but we have the opportunity to do something positive to empathise with the feelings of our fellow countrymen, many of whom will have a history of slavery in their family long ago.The Vale council has been contacted for a response. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: covid vaccine rolled across wales coming days
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThis morning it was announced the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agencyhad authorised the first vaccine as safe and effective on the basis of detailed independent expert review of evidence from large scale clinical trials.The Pfizer Biontech vaccine has become the first to receive MHRA clearance in the UK and  million doses of the vaccine will shortly be available for delivery across the UK, with Wales getting its allocation based on population.Approval from the MHRA is the first step of Walesrsquo roll-out plan, which has seen preparations on-going since May.There are still a number of stages which need to happen before the vaccine reaches those in highest need and is ready for use, but this process is expected to happen over the next week.These stages includeThe Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationfinalising and publishing their guidance for the whole of the UKFinalising training materials for staff and patient information leafletsTraining of experienced immunisers for this particular vaccineFinal legal frameworks to allow registered health professionals to administer the vaccine to patients need to be authorised by each Health Board in Wales.The vaccine - which needs to be administered in two doses - will initially be prioritised and available for those aged  and over, care home staff and residents and those working within health and social care.As further supplies become available and additional vaccines receive MHRA approval, a staged approach will see other groups offered the vaccine, based on risk of serious complications and deaths.Iniduals in the priority groups for a Covid- vaccine will receive an invitation from their employer or health board, providing information about the vaccines, telling them where to go and what to do on the day of their appointment.People are urged to wait to be invited, and not to ask their pharmacist or GP.The chief medical officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton, said: ldquoIt is fantastic to finally say that the first Covid- vaccine has been given the green light."We know now that we have a safe and effective vaccine for use across the UK - this is the positive news I and so many across the country have been waiting for.ldquoAll our NHS organisations across Wales have embraced the challenge presented to them and are at the advanced stages of planning for the arrival of a vaccine."We have tested distribution and storage arrangements to ensure we can get vaccine safely to every part of Wales.ldquoTherersquos still a few stages we need to work through but once all these safeguards are in place, vaccination can begin."There will only be relatively small amounts of the vaccine at first, those who have been advised as most needing the vaccine first, through approved delivery mechanisms."A full announcement around the timetable for roll-out in Wales will follow in the next few days.The effects of the vaccine may not be seen nationally for many months and the advice on keeping Wales safe remains the same for everyone, warned the first minister.Mark Drakeford said: "Todayrsquos news is a small glimmer of light at the end of what has been a long and dark tunnel.ldquoWe know some people within our communities are much more at risk than others from the serious complications of Covid-, which is why the new vaccine is being prioritised to protect them first.ldquoWhilst these first doses are given at fixed sites and occupational settings, and to protect our NHS and social care services, we must all continue to do our bit to prevent the spread of coronavirus: regular hand washing, social distancing, and wearing a face covering where required to protect yourself and others.Pfizer Biontech vaccine needs to be stored at ultra-low temperatures. These centres have already been decided by health boards and are in the process of being prepared.The development process for coronavirus vaccines has been as stringent as any other but the process in the face of the pandemic has been sped up by prompt, world-wide funding and a reduction in paperwork.Theof the trials have not been shortened, and the usual safety measures remain in place.The vaccine will not be mandatory and people will be able to choose whether they take up the vaccine or not.Information will be provided to people before vaccination to reassure them about patient safety and robust consent processes will be in place.Vice-chairman of the Covid- Vaccine Programme Board, Richard Roberts from Public Health Wales, said: ldquoIt is a signicant achievement that only  months after WHOannounced the global pandemic that we now have the first safe and effective vaccine available for use in Wales, and other vaccines to follow."Everyone has been preparing for months to deliver the Covid- vaccine programme, and it is very exciting that we will be able to begin, once the final steps have been put in place so that the programme can be delivered safely. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. I wouldnrsquot be surprised to see a spike in cases as a result of this decision.All pub and bar owners that spoke to the Penarth Times said they are concerned about what happens after the next review on December , with the majority saying they do not believe pubs will be able to serve alcohol until January.Health minister Vaughan Gething said he understood why companies in the industry are upset, but admitted there is "no perfect balance" between protecting public health and businesses.Health minister Vaughan GethingBut Brains CEO Alistair Darby told the Penarth Times he feels the government has got the balance wrong.Brains pubs including the Windsor and the Star Inn in Dinas Powys will close on Friday.ldquo, people have come through our doors since the start of the pandemic ndash seven staff members have tested positive in that time and test and trace have contacted us five times, said Mr Darby.ldquoI wonrsquot question the science behind the government decision, but it seems to me wersquove shown what wersquove done has worked.ldquoWersquove worked tirelessly to make sure people are as safe as possible in our pubs, and people have been safe. They help her with homework so I can get some work done. It is everyday problems which has hit everyone hard.ldquoI thought the trail would help lt peoplersquos spirits, take the pressure off us all a little, and we also didnrsquot know when we organised it what would be allowed.ldquoWersquove been extra careful, and people can follow the trail virtually on Facebook, and they can go for a walk and see the houses lit up.Mrs Yorke says she was stunned so many people put themselves forward for the trail, which has also been watched in Mexico and Australia.Karen and Mike Martins design at Queens Road, which was the December  revealldquoI posted it on the parents Facebook page and we just had an influx of messages, itrsquos been brilliant, she added.ldquoWe had to plan an easy trail close to the town centre which helped us get it down to , and then we set up a group to organise each day.The switch-ons ndash broadcast on Facebook by Michael every evening until December  ndash have gone seamlessly so far.After December  the pictures of all the homes involved will be posted on the Penarth Christmas Advent Window Trail Facebook page, and the lights will stay on until January .To follow the rest of the Christmas advent trail visithttps:www.facebook groups   and request to the join the group. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Time is in very short supply and we are at a very dficult point in the talks.ldquoWhat is certain is we will not be able to agree a deal that doesnrsquot respect our fundamental principles on sovereignty, fishing and control.ldquoOur negotiating team is working extremely hard in order to bridge the gaps that remain.We agreed to pause the talks in order to brief our Principals on the state of play of the negotiations. President @vonderleyen and Prime Minister Johnson will discuss the state of play tomorrow afternoon.mdash Michel BarnierDecember , After months of circling round the same key issues, there had been hopes that this weekend would be the point when the two sides would finally make the moves needed to get an agreement over the line.At the same time there had been an expectation that Mr Johnson and Mrs von der Leyen would have to come together to resolve the most problematic issues.With little time left for the two sides to raty any agreement before the end of the year, the pressure exposed underlying tensions within the EU.Irish premier Micheal Martin, whose country is expected to be among the biggest losersthe two sides failed to reach an agreement, said he ldquofervently hoped there would be a deal.In comments apparently aimed at the French, he said the negotiators had to be given the space to conclude their discussions. vw,vw,px, px"Taoiseach Micheal Martin says he lsquoferventlyrsquo hopes there will be a deal ldquoI have faith and trust in the EU negotiating team, in Michel Barnier and in president Ursula von der Leyen, he said.ldquoThere have been some countries putting pressure on wanting to seek additional information ndash  states canrsquot negotiate collectively.ldquoWersquove got to allow them the space to conclude their talks and hopefully achieve an agreement out of this.Meanwhile, Mr Beaune, an ally of President Emmanuel Macron, told Europe  radio that France will not accept a deal with ldquobad terms.ldquoIf a good agreement cannot be reached, we will oppose it. title: ministers outline new covid  regulations
story: MINISTERS have outlined a package of measures agreed by the Executive that will come into effect at the end of the two week circuit breaker. Shops, hairdressers, restaurants, places of worship and hotels are among the places that will be able to re-open from December . Pubs selling drink onlywill remain closed and an additional financial package will be put in place. The Executive has also agreed Christmas household bubbling arrangements from December -. Three households will be able to come together for this period in domestic settings, outdoor public spaces and places of worship. One of the households will be able to include their existing household bubble. First Minister Arlene Foster said: “Through our collective efforts over recent weeks we gained enough space in the transmission of the virus to relax a signicant number of restrictions, including the opening-up of non-essential retail, close contact services, sport and leisure activities and our places of worship at the end of next week. “These decisions will give families, businesses and employees some much-needed certainty and comfort in the run-up to Christmas and beyond. “This is a special time of the year and we want to support people to have a good Christmas, but also a safe one. “Signicant work has been completed with business sectors, faith groups, local government and police on new mitigation measures to reduce the risk of transmission. “I urge everyone to be Covid-aware and to make careful and sensible decisions when out and about or mixing with others. We need to make sure we continue doing all we can to protect ourselves and our loved ones.” Deputy First Minister Michelle O’Neill said: “The Executive wants to give people as much notice as possible on what the situation will look like from next Friday when the current circuit breaker comes to an end. “We have given detailed consideration to which restrictions need tobe maintained, and what we can open up, in light of the scientic and medical advice. “A package of measures that will see signicant relaxations to the current restrictions has been agreed, with maximum mitigations in place to minimise risks to the greatest extent possible. An additional support package will be put in place for traditional drink-only pubs that unfortunately will not be able to reopen at this time. “We appreciate how important Christmas time is for many families and the Executive has agreed arrangements that will allow families and friends to come together in a limited way between  and  December. “It’s important for people to understand that with any increased contact comes increased risk. Everyone needs to think very carefully about the risks posed to them, and their loved ones, by coming together over the Christmas period, particularly to those who are vulnerable. Some may choose not to form a Christmas bubble but for those who do, we encourage them to keep their bubbles small and limit the numbers of people gathering, as much as possible.”  addthis,     Leave
